Variables
SharpNeat.​Tasks.​PreyCapture
namespace SharpNeat.Tasks.PreyCapture
PreyCaptureWorld
public sealed
PreyCaptureWorld

The prey capture task's grid world, as defined in:  Incremental Evolution Of Complex General Behavior, Faustino Gomez and Risto Miikkulainen (1997) http://​nn​.cs​.utexas​.edu​/downloads​/papers​/gomez​.adaptive-behavior​.pdf  Encapsulates the agent's sensor and motor hardware, and the prey's simple stochastic movement.

The grid world's origin, i.e. coordinate (0,0), is at the bottom left of the grid.

Constants
__gridSize
const int __gridSize

The length of an edge of the square grid world, measured in grid squares. The minimum possible value here is 9, otherwise the initial position of the agent may be outside of the grid world, and also the agent wall detectors would all be always on.

__atan2LookupOffset
const int __atan2LookupOffset

Parameters
preyInitMoves
int

Prey initial moves. The number of moves the prey is allowed to move before the agent can move.

preySpeed
float

Prey speed; in the interval [0, 1].

sensorRange
float

The sensor range of the agent.

maxTimesteps
int

The maximum number of simulation timesteps to run without the agent capturing the prey.

Functions
RunTrial
public bool RunTrial(
IBlackBox<double> agent
)

Runs one trial of the provided agent in the world. Returns true if the agent captures the prey within the maximum number of timesteps allowed.

Parameter
agent
IBlackBox<double>

The agent to run the trail with.

Returns

True if the agent captured the prey; otherwise false.

InitPositions
public void InitPositions()

Initialise agent and prey positions. The prey is positioned randomly with at least 4 empty squares between it and a wall (in all directions).  The agent is positioned randomly but such that the prey is within sensor range (distance 2 or less).

SetAgentInputsAndActivate
public void SetAgentInputsAndActivate(
IBlackBox<double> agent
)

Determine the agent's position in the world relative to the prey and walls, and set its sensor inputs accordingly.

Parameter
agent
IBlackBox<double>

The agent.

MoveAgent
public void MoveAgent(
IBlackBox<double> agent
)

Allow the agent to move one square based on its decision. Note that the agent can choose to not move.

Parameter
agent
IBlackBox<double>

The agent.

MovePrey
public void MovePrey()

Move the prey. The prey moves by a simple set of stochastic rules that make it more likely to move away from the agent with increased proximity to the agent.

IsPreyCaptured
public bool IsPreyCaptured()

Gets a boolean that indicates if the prey has been captured.

Returns

True if the agent has captured the prey; otherwise false.

T
private static float T(
float distance
)

The T function as defined in Appendix A of the paper referenced at the top of this class.  This is a function on the distance between the agent and the prey, with it's maximum value of 15 when distance is zero, and minimum value of 1.0 when distance is greater than 15.

Parameter
distance
float

Distance between the agent and the prey.

CartesianToPolar
private static void CartesianToPolar(
Int32Point p,
out int radiusSqr,
out float azimuth
)

Convert the given integer Cartesian coordinate to a polar coordinate.

The radius coordinate is returned as the *square* of the radius. This is because normally we want to compare the radius with some threshold, and it's faster to avoid a square root operation to calculate the radius, and instead to compare squared radii.  By convention the polar axis is horizontal and to the right, and a positive azimuth represents an anticlockwise rotation. Therefore an azimuth of zero degrees represents due east (note. this same angle is never represented by +360 degrees), and an angle of +90 degrees represents due north.

Parameters
p
Int32Point

The integer Cartesian coordinate to convert.

radiusSqr
out int

Returns the square of the radius, as an integer. I.e. the distance from the pole, squared.

azimuth
out float

Returns the azimuth; the anticlockwise angle from the polar axis.

Exp
static float Exp(
float x
)

Returns e raised to the specified power.

This approximate function is customised for use in the prey capture task, and gives reasonable results over the interval [0, 2*PI].  As such this function should not be used elsewhere as a general purpose approximation for exp().

Parameter
x
float

A number specifying a power.

Returns

The number e raised to the power x.
